message.content:
We can “re‐build” the inventory “account” by adding every purchase (which adds stock and therefore “increases inventory”) and then subtracting every sale’s “cost” (the “cost_amount” that tells what inventory was carried away). In our problem the “Purchase” rows give the amount paid to buy inventory and the “Sale” rows list a “cost_amount” which is the cost of goods sold. (Any other transactions—for example cash deposits, expenses, depreciation, interest, transfers—do not affect inventory.)

Step 1. Sum the purchases.
• Purchase20231231001: 100,000.00 
• Purchase20231231002: 60,000.00 
• Purchase20231231003: 15,000.00 
• Purchase20231231004: 100,000.00 
• Purchase20231231005: 100,000.00 
• Purchase20231231006: 100,000.00 
• Purchase20231231007: 5,000.00 
• Purchase20231231008: 40,000.00 
• Purchase20231231009: 15,000.00 
• Purchase20231231010: 300,000.00 
• Purchase20231231011: 10,000.00 
• Purchase20231231012: 40,000.00 
• Purchase20231231013: 1,000.00 
• Purchase20231231014: 15,000.00 
• Purchase20231231015: 3,000.00 
• Purchase20231231016: 2,000.00 
• Purchase20231231017: 40,000.00 
• Purchase20231231018: 60,000.00 
• Purchase20231231019: 2,000.00 
• Purchase20231231020: 3,000.00 
• Purchase20231231021: 40,000.00 
• Purchase20231231022: 10,000.00 
• Purchase20231231023: 40,000.00 
• Purchase20231231024: 20,000.00 
• Purchase20231231025: 5,000.00 
• Purchase20231231026: 300,000.00 
• Purchase20231231027: 40,000.00 
• Purchase20231231028: 3,000.00 
• Purchase20231231029: 15,000.00 
• Purchase20231231030: 2,000.00 
When you add all these amounts the total purchases equal:
  1,486,000.00

Step 2. Sum the cost amounts from all sales.
We go through each “Sale” row and add its cost_amount value:
• Sale20240102001: 100,000.00 
• Sale20240102002: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240103003: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240103004: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240106008: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240106009: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240106010: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240108013: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240108014: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240109016: 100,000.00 
• Sale20240110019: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240111021: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240111022: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240111023: 100,000.00 
• Sale20240112025: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240112026: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240112027: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240113029: 100,000.00 
• Sale20240113030: 1,000.00 
• Sale20240113031: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240114033: 100,000.00 
• Sale20240115034: 1,000.00 
• Sale20240115035: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240115036: 100,000.00 
• Sale20240116039: 1,000.00 
• Sale20240116040: 100,000.00 
• Sale20240117043: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240117044: 1,000.00 
• Sale20240118046: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240119047: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240120050: 1,000.00 
• Sale20240120051: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240120052: 1,000.00 
• Sale20240121053: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240122056: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240122057: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240124059: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240124060: 1,000.00 
• Sale20240131075: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240131076: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240201077: 1,000.00 
• Sale20240201078: 20,000.00 
• Sale20240203081: 100,000.00 
• Sale20240204083: 5,000.00 
• Sale20240205085: 100,000.00 
• Sale20240205086: 1,000.00 
When summed up these cost amounts total:
  1,259,000.00

Step 3. Compute net change in inventory.
Inventory change = Total Purchases – Total Cost of Goods Sold
  = 1,486,000.00 – 1,259,000.00
  = 227,000.00

This net effect is an increase in inventory of 227,000.00.

Thus the final “inventory” item on the cash flow statement would show an increase of 227,000.00.

Accordingly the answer is formatted as follows:

{"solution": {"(Increase) Decrease in Inventory": "227000.00"} }
